deltas.text: Knowing SI Units lets you solve a lot of problems when you don't remember the exact formulas.
The Coulomb is a unit measuring charge. Amperes measure the flow of charge, so they are Coulombs per second.
Joules measure energy, and Watts measure energy per second, or power.
Volts measure how much energy it takes to move charge, so their unit is energy per charge or Joules per Coulomb.
Ohms measure resistance, and using Ohm's law (V=I/R) it follows that Ohms are Volts per Ampere.
Farads measure the amount of charge stored per volt, so they are Coulombs per Volt.
Henries measure the amount of voltage dropped in proportion to change in current over time, so they are Volt-seconds per Ampere.
That last one can also be written as Ohm-seconds, and Farads can also be expressed as seconds per Ohm.
This becomes useful when you analyse RL and RC circuits.
